A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

1. Your full name: Adam Ebb

2. Your address: 416-2nd St East, Saskatoon, Sask.

3. Date: May 25th, 1971

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country).
   Odessa, (city) in province Odessa Russia.

5. What was your father's name and occupation?
   Raphael Ebb, Mechanic, Manufacturing, etc.

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year).
   June 1st, 1905.

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.
   Aberdeen, South Dakota, U.S.A., 1898 - moved to Sawyer, North Dakota in 1900.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child;" "I was in my teens;" etc.)
   I was thirteen years old.

9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   As I was only 13 yrs old I came with my parents' family of one sister and four brothers, along with eight other families from the Dakotas who were mostly German speaking people, who had emigrated from Russia. Saskatchewan was described to us as a land of opportunity.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)
    We learned or first heard about Saskatchewan through a Roman Catholic priest & Rev. Father William Brabender (German nationality) who came from Canada & acted as an agent to encourage settlers to come to Saskatchewan & take up homesteads. Each man 18 yrs or over was entitled to 160 acres at a cost of $10.00 to register. A homesteader had to stay at least 3 years and improve at least 45 acres in that period before receiving title to the land.

9. What were your reasons for coming West? Answer: To escape the poverty and hardship along with my parents' family of nine people and many brothers along with myself. We came from the Ukraine, who were mostly farmers, seeking a better life and a land of opportunity.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?) Answer: Learned about it from friends about the West. Railroads advertised extensively in newspapers and magazines.
To answer questions, 13, 14, & 15.

We traveled by train, the families were in immigration cars, each family brought their personal belongings, bedding etc., and were allowed some machinery; each family could bring about ten head of livestock, cattle & horses, these came in livestock cars.

We came up through Moose Jaw & Regina when we arrived in Saskatoon we were delayed for two weeks, as we had to wait for the railway to be completed in order to travel to Battleford, Sask., which was then just a fort.

The train moved so slowly, that the men were able to shoot game (which was very plentiful) while the train was moving, they were able to leave the train, run out & pick up the deer, antelope or whatever they shot & get back on the crawling train.

On our arrival at Battleford the women and smaller children stayed in an immigration hall for several weeks, while the men and older boys continued their journey in covered wagons & horses.

Their destination was an area sixty five mile south of Battleford, near a salt water
Lake, now known as Dramping Lake, there they built shelters out of sod for the animals and also sod huts for their families. It was several weeks before they returned to Battleford to get their families.

Our first winter in Saskatchewan was very mild, we were able to gather firewood and haul fresh water from springs which for some families was many miles from their home. When possible snow was melted, many times family members stayed up all night melting snow in order to have enough water for the family use and the animals as well.

In the earlier years about once each winter a group of neighbors representing each of the families would travel the sixty-five miles to Battleford by open bobsled horses to get supplies.

Although most of the settlers in that area were German-Russian descent, and of the Roman Catholic faith, among our neighbors were Welsh, Scotch and American born people.

The first year we were settled a prairie fire destroyed all the grass for approximately a hundred miles area, we could see and smell the smoke for days before the fire arrived from the west border of Saskatchewan.

Some hay that had been cut was moved far enough ahead of the fire to be saved; this was later mixed with bullrushes from the lake and fed to the animals the following winter.

Hundreds of coyotes roamed the prairies which the settlers shot when they could. The hides sold for twenty-five to seventy-five cents each. Although the coyotes were known to chew up livestock they really did not bother them too much.

Lumber was available after the railway was extended to what is the town of Unity.

One incident that comes to my mind regarding Indians was a comment made by a foreman in Battleford when we first arrived (I believe the store was called Prince Brothers store). He said it was the first time he had met any Americans & he fully expected us to be Indians from the U.S.A.

Later when we were settled I recall the time when a group of Indians stopped in our settlement when they were travelling from Medicine Hat to Battleford. They wanted some flour which we had. I traded to them for other items, from them I bought a three-year-old riding pony for the sum of $1.00. Only one young Indian was able to interpret our broken English in order to make the trades.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)? We came with a group of eight families, each averaged about six children, possibly fifty people.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan. In 1926 my wife and family moved to Princeton, B.C., then in 1928 we moved back to Leask (Macklin) where I lived until 1946 when we moved to Saskatoon. For several months during 1951 my wife and I lived at God's Delight, but where I was employed by the Saskatchewan Govt. on a construction job.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came? When I left Russia I was only 18 years old, 15 years of age when I came to Leask. At 18 I took up the homestead farm until 1921 when I bought the dairy farm and dairy business at Leask. From 1922 to 1928 I was a construction millwright in British Columbia. 24. Did you travel about much in the early years? For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.? How often? How far? By what means of travel?
There are many memories both of happy times and of great hardships. In these early years there were no strangers in our community. We not only knew all our neighbors for miles and miles around, but we often knew their parents and grandparents as well.

There was no compulsory schooling for my generation; most of us barely received the equivalent of grade three, our main education was one of hard work & early responsibility. Relatives and neighbors went out of their way to help each other and to share what little they had.

Every religious holiday, anniversary or name day was a reason for gatherings and celebrations; there was no generation gap, everyone was welcome from great grandparents down to the newest baby.

Weddings especially were well celebrated events; often lasting for three days, with huge quantities of food prepared by willing hands of friends and relatives, it was always an honor to be invited to help. There was no license needed to serve the gallons of home made wines and brew consumed on these occasions.

three generations, the elders members always receiving respect and concern from the younger ones.

Possibly the flu epidemic after the first world war was the saddest experience of our generation, entire families were ill at once; our two doctors, Dr. Laffin who could not possibly get around to all the sick people in the wide area had to travel by horse & buggy. So many people of all ages died, there were times when there was no one strong enough to dig the graves.

In some instances people who died during the winters were stored in granary or barns, to be buried the following spring. Sometimes the body was attacked by mice by then.

Some of my pleasantest memories are of early morning shooting trips, ducks, geese, prairie chickens were so plentiful around the lakes & sloughs where we lived, it was not uncommon for two or three neighbors to get together and come home with fifty birds before breakfast time.

Methods of election campaigning were unusual in the very early days, I recall a couple of election years.

19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home? To my knowledge, my parents had no correspondence to Kansas—possibly the odd letter to relatives in North Dakota—I wrote to them once in 1912—mostly messages were sent through personal visits later on. The families who moved to Saskatchewan brought news from our family friends in the Dakotas.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage. My wife was Ada Block, of the Sixth Roman Catholic district just across the Alberta border near Maclean, Saskatchewan. We were married on April 1st, 1913, at St. Rose Church.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle? My father recommended it to people in the Dakotas and Nebraska, although personal messages sent by travellers who returned knew how to vote.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West, tell when they came and where they settled. Since we were all young, we came at the same time, my four brothers and one sister all married people of the same nationality and settled in the same district, in fact, we five brothers all lived in the same township for a time. Some of my brothers' wives have passed away, along with my parents, and all survive in the village of Dalwood, Saskatchewan. My only living brother resides at the Union Home in Unity, Saskatchewan.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel? Some of us rode horseback, some traveled by buggy (single seat) or democrat buggy (two or three seats). In the winter, by horseback or closed car cutters. Approx. 1909 I recall going to the town of Sota for supplies about every two weeks, a distance of 1/4 mile from our home, a small church was built on my father's land (short of food also), our priest was Dr. Brown, Bishop & Dr. Louie. Most families were within 6 miles or so of this church.

25. When was the first car used in the community? I recall an American car, a 4 cylinder McLaughlin about 1916.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make? I bought my first car, a model T Ford in 1913; it cost $500.00.

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home? Most of my trading was done at Leduc, or at Unity, which was about 10 miles from my homestead.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.) Yes, I did until Brandon West.

29. How often did you shop in the early days? Only a couple of times a year when needed to go to Battleford, later to villages like Leduc, Unity, Leduc, Red Deer, and including events such as fairs.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays? Locally around 1914-1920 when silent movies first appeared, also any live attraction like a Chataqua (variety show in a huge round tent) served bring the people together.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period. I can remember buying through Eaton's Catalogue about 1912-13. Mostly clothing was bought this way—clothes in a suit with a complete outfit for the season. Prices were between $10.00 to $15.00 per dollar. In 1914—a man was paid $5.00 per day ($1.00 and 8 cents) at seeding time. Apron overall could be purchased for $3.00 to $5.00, a suit for $5.00 to $13.50—a good fur coat for $20.00—work shirt & pants $1.00 ea.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it? About 1915 the first rural telephone—these settlers came here holding (to end) to individual farms, some cost $5.00 an annual rate of $25.00 to $28.00 to $30.00 per year.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan this first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision? My parents came with the intention of staying. Later when I was 18 I started my own homestead. By then we were allowed twice as much land as the first settlers, at a cost of $3.00 per acre from the Government.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

I was a councillor & school trustee of Grass Lake municipality at some period from 1916 to 1920. One brother was president of wheat pool at some time during these early years. I was on the council at Macklin back in the 30's. I was always interested in the Denis economy & taxation. I have always had a strong interest in the local enterprises, was on the negotiating committee on a couple of occasions. Although retired I still attend both executive and regular Union meetings every month.
